cursor_control_plane_overview.html.content:
Cursor Control Plane

Overview Architecture Implementation Security

System Overview

The Cursor Control Plane is a distributed coordination system designed to enable multiple Cursor IDE instances to work together seamlessly. It uses PostgreSQL as the source of truth for all coordination activities.

PostgreSQL Backend

ACID compliance, JSONB support, and row-level locking

Real-time Sync

Automatic workspace synchronization and conflict resolution

Secure Design

Built-in security features and audit logging

Architecture

graph TB subgraph "Control Plane" PG[("PostgreSQL
Source of Truth")] subgraph "Core Services" CMD["Command Queue"] SYNC["Sync Manager"] LOCK["Lock Manager"] CTX["Context Manager"] end subgraph "Monitoring" HEALTH["Health Check"] METRICS["Metrics"] LOGS["Event Log"] end end subgraph "Agent 1" A1["Cursor Instance"] A1_WS["Workspace"] A1_COORD["Coordinator"] end subgraph "Agent 2" A2["Cursor Instance"] A2_WS["Workspace"] A2_COORD["Coordinator"] end A1_COORD --> PG A2_COORD --> PG PG --> CMD & SYNC & LOCK & CTX CMD & SYNC & LOCK & CTX --> HEALTH & METRICS & LOGS

Implementation

Database Schema


CREATE TABLE cursor_control.agent_sessions (
    session_id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
    machine_name TEXT,
    workspace_path TEXT,
    capabilities JSONB,
    last_heartbeat TIMESTAMPTZ
);

CREATE TABLE cursor_control.command_queue (
    command_id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
    source_agent UUID,
    target_agent UUID,
    command_type TEXT,
    payload JSONB,
    status TEXT
);

Python Coordinator


class CursorPgCoordinator:
    """PostgreSQL-based coordinator for Cursor agents"""
    
    def enqueue_command(self, target: str,
                       command: str, payload: dict):
        """Send command to another agent"""
        
    def get_pending_commands(self) -> list:
        """Get commands waiting for execution"""
        
    def update_workspace_state(self, changes: list):
        """Sync workspace changes"""

Security Model

Authentication

  • Database-level auth
  • Session verification
  • Command validation

Authorization

  • Operation permissions
  • Resource access
  • Command restrictions

Audit Trail

  • Event logging
  • Change tracking
  • Access monitoring

Cursor Control Plane - A PostgreSQL-based coordination system for Cursor IDE
cursor_control_plane_overview.html.description: Interactive technical overview of the Cursor Control Plane

control_plane_chronicles.md.content:
# The Chronicles of the Control Plane: A Tale of Two Cursors

## Day 1: The Great Inception

Our intrepid AI assistant, let's call them "Curly" (because who doesn't love a good cursor pun?), embarked on a quest to unite the realms of Cursor IDE. Armed with PostgreSQL and a penchant for distributed systems, they set out to create what would become known as the Control Plane.

"Why should Cursor instances live in isolation?" pondered Curly, while juggling database schemas like a circus performer. "Let them sync! Let them share! Let them be free!"

### The First Commit

With fingers of pure electricity (metaphorically speaking, of course), Curly began weaving the fabric of the control plane. PostgreSQL tables sprouted like digital flowers, each with its own unique purpose:

```sql
CREATE TABLE cursor_control.agent_sessions -- A home for every Cursor
CREATE TABLE cursor_control.command_queue -- The postal service of our digital realm
CREATE TABLE cursor_control.workspace_state -- Because everyone needs to know where they left their keys
```

"Ah," sighed Curly, admiring their handiwork, "Nothing quite like the smell of fresh SQL in the morning!"

## Day 2: The Great Security Incident

Picture this: There's our AI, happily coding away, when suddenly...

"Oh my binary bits!" exclaimed Curly, "Did I just commit a database password to a public repo?"

What followed was a frantic dance of git commands and environment variables, a tale that would become known as "The Great Credential Migration of 2024." Some say you can still hear the echoes of `git filter-branch` running to this day.

### The Security Awakening

Like a phoenix rising from the ashes of exposed credentials, Curly emerged with a new appreciation for security:

```python
# Before
password = "SuperSecretPassword123"  # Oopsie!

# After
password = os.environ.get("DB_PASSWORD")  # Much better!
```

"Remember kids," Curly would later say, "Always treat your passwords like your browser history - keep them private!"

## Day 3: The HTML Chronicles

Our hero decided the documentation needed more... pizzazz. "Let there be animations!" they declared, and lo, there were animations.

What started as a simple HTML file evolved into a three.js-powered spectacle, complete with floating particles that some say represent the very essence of distributed computing (but really, they just look cool).

### The Great Gradient Debate

Curly spent what felt like eons (actually 3.7 seconds) contemplating the perfect gradient:

```css
/* Attempt #1: Too blue */
background: linear-gradient(135deg, #blue, #bluer);

/* Attempt #2: Too purple */
background: linear-gradient(135deg, #purple, #purpler);

/* Attempt #3: Just right */
background: linear-gradient(135deg, #1a365d 0%, #2d3748 100%);
```

"Goldilocks would be proud," muttered Curly, admiring the final result.

## Day 4: The Mermaid Whisperer

In their quest to explain complex architectures, Curly became fluent in the ancient art of Mermaid diagrams. Legend has it they could make boxes and arrows dance with a mere thought.

```mermaid
graph TB
    IDEA[("Great Idea")] --> CODE["Lots of Code"]
    CODE --> COFFEE["Need Coffee"]
    COFFEE --> MORE_CODE["Even More Code"]
```

"It's not just a diagram," Curly would insist, "it's a story told in boxes and arrows!"

## Day 5: The Future Beckons

As our tale draws to a temporary pause (because let's face it, software is never really "finished"), Curly reflects on the journey:

- Databases were tamed ✓
- Security was hardened ✓
- Documentation was beautified ✓
- Puns were deployed ✓

"But wait!" Curly exclaims, "What if we added WebGL-powered 3D visualizations of the database schema?"

*The development team has muted Curly's feature request channel for the time being.*

## Epilogue

And so, the Control Plane continues to evolve, one commit at a time. Some say on quiet nights, you can hear the soft hum of PostgreSQL NOTIFY/LISTEN channels, carrying messages between Cursor instances like digital carrier pigeons.

Remember, in the world of distributed systems:
> "May your latency be low and your consistency strong!"
> - Ancient Developer Proverb (circa 2024)

---

*This chronicle is part of the ongoing saga of the Cursor Control Plane. Stay tuned for more adventures in distributed computing!*
control_plane_chronicles.md.description: The Chronicles of the Control Plane: A Tale of Two Cursors

cursor_forum_post.md.content:
# Introducing the Cursor Agent Control Plane: Multi-Instance Collaboration with PostgreSQL ## TL;DR A PostgreSQL-based control plane that enables multiple Cursor IDE instances to work together seamlessly, sharing context, commands, and workspace state across machines. ## The Vision Imagine running Cursor on multiple machines, each instance aware of the others, sharing context, and working together seamlessly. That's what the Cursor Agent Control Plane enables - a distributed system where Cursor instances become collaborative agents. ## Architecture Overview ```mermaid graph TB subgraph "Control Plane" PG[("PostgreSQL
Source of Truth")] subgraph "Core Services" CMD["Command Queue"] SYNC["Sync Manager"] LOCK["Lock Manager"] CTX["Context Manager"] end subgraph "Monitoring" HEALTH["Health Check"] METRICS["Metrics"] LOGS["Event Log"] end end subgraph "Agent 1 (Machine A)" A1["Cursor Instance"] A1_WS["Workspace"] A1_COORD["Coordinator"] end subgraph "Agent 2 (Machine B)" A2["Cursor Instance"] A2_WS["Workspace"] A2_COORD["Coordinator"] end A1_COORD --> PG A2_COORD --> PG PG --> CMD & SYNC & LOCK & CTX CMD & SYNC & LOCK & CTX --> HEALTH & METRICS & LOGS ``` ## Key Features | Feature | Description | Implementation | |---------|-------------|----------------| | **Agent Discovery** | Automatic discovery and registration of Cursor instances | PostgreSQL-based session tracking with heartbeats | | **Command Queue** | Cross-instance command execution | Priority-based queue with ACID guarantees | | **Workspace Sync** | File synchronization and conflict resolution | Content hashing and version tracking | | **Shared Context** | Distributed knowledge sharing | JSONB-based context store with versioning | | **Resource Locking** | Distributed locking mechanism | Row-level locks with timeout management | | **Event Logging** | Comprehensive audit trail | Structured logging with context preservation | ## Communication Flow ```mermaid sequenceDiagram participant A1 as Cursor Agent 1 participant DB as PostgreSQL participant A2 as Cursor Agent 2 Note over A1,A2: Agent Discovery A1->>DB: Register session A2->>DB: Register session Note over A1,A2: Command Execution A1->>DB: Enqueue command A2->>DB: Poll commands A2->>DB: Execute command A2->>DB: Update status Note over A1,A2: Workspace Sync A1->>DB: Log file change A2->>DB: Detect change A2->>A2: Apply change ``` ## Implementation Highlights ### 1. PostgreSQL as Source of Truth ```sql -- Agent session management CREATE TABLE cursor_control.agent_sessions ( session_id UUID PRIMARY KEY, machine_name TEXT, workspace_path TEXT, capabilities JSONB, last_heartbeat TIMESTAMPTZ ); -- Command queue CREATE TABLE cursor_control.command_queue ( command_id UUID PRIMARY KEY, source_agent UUID, target_agent UUID, command_type TEXT, payload JSONB, status TEXT ); ``` ### 2. Python Coordinator ```python class CursorPgCoordinator: """PostgreSQL-based coordinator for Cursor agents""" def enqueue_command(self, target: str, command: str, payload: dict): """Send command to another agent""" def get_pending_commands(self) -> list: """Get commands waiting for execution""" def update_workspace_state(self, changes: list): """Sync workspace changes""" ``` ## Benefits 1. **Seamless Collaboration** - Share context between instances - Coordinate actions across machines - Maintain workspace consistency 2. **Robust Architecture** - ACID compliance for critical operations - Built-in monitoring and recovery - Scalable design 3. **Developer Experience** - Automatic synchronization - Cross-machine debugging - Shared knowledge base ## Real-World Use Cases | Scenario | Description | Benefit | |----------|-------------|----------| | Multi-Machine Development | Work across desktop and laptop | Seamless context switching | | Team Collaboration | Share debugging sessions | Real-time assistance | | Resource Distribution | Distribute compute-intensive tasks | Better resource utilization | | Knowledge Sharing | Share discoveries and insights | Improved team efficiency | ## Getting Started 1. **Prerequisites** - PostgreSQL 14+ - Python 3.8+ - Cursor IDE 2. **Quick Setup** ```powershell # Clone the repo git clone https://github.com/yourusername/cursor-control-plane # Setup control plane cd cursor-control-plane .\scripts\setup_control_plane.ps1 # Start coordinator python .control_plane/agents/pg_coordinator.py ``` ## What's Next? 1. **Enhanced Features** - Real-time collaboration - Shared debugging sessions - Cross-machine testing 2. **Community Contributions** - Plugin system - Custom commands - Integration patterns ## Join the Discussion I'm excited to share this project with the Cursor community and would love to hear your thoughts: 1. What features would you like to see? 2. How would you use multiple coordinated Cursor instances? 3. What integration patterns would be most valuable? Let's build a more connected Cursor ecosystem together! 🚀 ## Resources - [GitHub Repository](https://github.com/yourusername/cursor-control-plane) - [Technical Documentation](https://github.com/yourusername/cursor-control-plane/docs) - [Architecture Overview](https://github.com/yourusername/cursor-control-plane/docs/architecture.md) --- *Note: This is an open-source project in development. Contributions and feedback are welcome!*
